body:
this says ZG(1) is sucky: https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01484099/document

this has a bunch of simulated settings possibly worth considering: https://reader.elsevier.com/reader/sd/pii/S0167947311004099?token=22CA3714EEC6A4B5FCC3DFD1759E133AACFB4CDC5F2CD66BC6CADE67B8DAB5B263ED7EEB6639E7C2C68B69DCEEB820A1
@asaadeldin11  some context if you end up looking at this
@jovo how'd you feel about an NDD student doing this sprint 1? It is not a code deliverable, it is an experiment/Jupyter notebook deliverable

issue.title: Compare ZG vs Minka
issue.body:
Paper for minka: https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3008751.3008835

Currently, `select_dimension` implements Zhu and Godsie (http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.90.3768&rep=rep1&type=pdf). Compare and contrast the performance of Minka and ZG.

body:
depends on the student.

How can I do better? <https://forms.gle/iEad8byD89eTPdYx6>
I am also interested in this one.

Check out the code in this package https://github.com/idc9/ya_pca/tree/master/ya_pca/rank_selection. We've worked with the developer on mvlearn, but it's PCA and lots of different rank selection methods including Minka.

They're compared in this [notebook](https://github.com/idc9/ya_pca/blob/master/docs/example_notebooks/PCA%20rank%20selection%20methods.ipynb) but it's a bit rough. See Minka and profile likelihood (ZG) at the bottom, note it's probably ZG(1) and this isn't graph-valued data.

it occurs to me that scipy should have one of these, which ever is 'best'
i'd guess ZG(2), but Minka is possible (or one of the others, i guess)

Iain and I had talked about the benefit of a `rank_selection` module or something that made it easy to use any of them (or the 'best' few) in any function that had a rank selections step.

> Iain and I had talked about the benefit of a `rank_selection` module or something that made it easy to use any of them (or the 'best' few) in any function that had a rank selections step.

Sounds like a great idea, seems like mvlearn + graspologic could both use. And whatever's best, as jovo says, would want to push into scipy/sklearn as appropriate. 

Is https://github.com/arvkevi/kneed in the notebook?

also just a note - looks like the ZG code was based on graspy but is not using the Carey trick (basically only check the first log2 singular values) so I would expect results different from ours on real data

right, only we will have those tricks.

ronan - seems like mvlearn will care too, maybe you/them might do the
experiment good to get something in scipy, which seems is where it should
go?

@dfrancisco1998 would you be interested in doing this instead of #579 ?

This is more overdue, so I think we'd like to get it done first.
I was intrigued by this but had some other things to wrap up first, certainly can help out until I have more time.
Note, sklearn's [PCA](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.decomposition.PCA.html) uses minka as an automatic selection.
